header.title: Full Guide To Becoming a Real Wizard, Witch or Necromancer

central_thesis: The book presents a comprehensive guide to becoming a practitioner of various magical arts by emphasizing an integrated approach: fostering a deep spiritual connection with a higher power (God) and the universe, cultivating inner power through systematic meditation and enlightenment, and then applying this foundation to practical rituals, spell casting, and the creation of magical tools within diverse esoteric traditions like ceremonial magic, Wicca, Druidism, and necromancy. It aims to demystify magic while providing a structured path for serious aspirants.

structure_content.summary: This section serves as an introduction to the 'quest' of becoming a magic practitioner, emphasizing the prerequisites of deep knowledge, an open mind, and sustained devotion. It warns against superficial engagement, stressing that true magic requires a systematic plan for lifestyle transformation and consistent practice.

Explores the diverse human perceptions of magic, contrasting rational dismissal with spiritual and deeply religious views. It highlights the often negative biblical stance on sorcery and witchcraft, yet positions genuine wizardry as seeking 'the approval of God,' not human acclaim. It stresses the importance of understanding one's motivation and the various forms of magic before choosing a path.

Defines the soul as the 'immaterial or eternal part of God' within all living and inanimate objects, serving as God's image and an 'avatar' monitored by one's soul. It introduces Kabbalistic (Nephesh, Ru'ah, Neshamah, Chayyah, Yehidah) and Egyptian (Ba, Ka, Akh) concepts of the soul and spirit, detailing their functions and roles in life, death, and magic.

Distinguishes magic from prayer: prayer requires a deity's assent, while magic is effective through the operation itself and the magician's will or command over spiritual beings. It asserts that magical failure stems from defects in casting, unlike prayer's failure attributed to God's will. Achieving 'Magical Enlightenment' enhances success.

Lists and briefly defines a wide array of magical traditions, including Alchemy, Animism, Black Magic, Candomblé, Ceremonial Magic, Chaos Magic, Druidry, Feri Tradition, Haitian Vodou, Hermeticism, Hoodoo, Huna, Kabbalah, Louisiana Voodoo, Nagual, Obeah, Onmyōdō, Palo, Pow-wow, Psychonautics, Quimbanda, Reiki, Santana, Santería, Satanism, Seid, Setianism, Sex Magic, Shamanism, Shinto, Sigil Magic, Taoism, Thelema, West African Vodun, Wicca, and Zos Kia Cultus.

Defines black magic as sorcery drawing on malevolent powers for killing, stealing, injuring, or personal gain. It presents the counter-argument that 'magic has no color' and can have benevolent uses (e.g., killing pests), suggesting no universal morality against which magic is measured. It notes the fictional association of black magic with evil.

Explores various theories on distinguishing black from white magic: the 'All as One' (all evil), 'Dark Doctrine' (powers of darkness), 'Formal Differences' (harmful vs. beneficial spell components), 'No Connection' (linguistically separate), 'Separate but Equal' (same magic, different intent), and 'Sun and Moon Magic' (day vs. night magic, not good/evil).

Classifies demons as human or non-human spirits, noting demonology's historical context as a study of superhuman beings. It describes beliefs about spirits controlling life's affairs in various cultures (Inuit, Korean, Babylonian, Mpongwe) and the Jewish Talmud's enumeration of demons.

Details methods for summoning and commanding demons using grimoires like 'Goetia' and 'The Book of Abramelin.' It contrasts this approach with 'demonolatry,' which involves prayer and petition rather than command, acknowledging different views on respectful interaction with these entities. It includes a seal for the demon 'Haures'.

Defines exorcism as the practice of evicting possessing demons or spiritual entities by causing them to swear an oath. It notes the ancient and widespread nature of this practice across many belief systems.

Introduces ceremonial magic as requiring consecrated tools and rituals, symbolizing psychological or metaphysical concepts. It lists essential tools (circle, altar, wand, cup, sword, pantacle, oil lamp, Book of Conjurations, Bell, crown, robe, lamen) and discusses grimoires and Enochian magic as key resources and systems.

Describes shamans as spiritual visionaries and gifted healers who communicate with the spirit world and use their sight to guide their people. It provides archaeological evidence for shamanic burials, highlighting their close relationship with animal spirits and the power of elements discovered by Egyptian wizards.

Introduces Kabbalah as a Jewish mystical discipline explaining the relationship between the Creator and the universe. It details the soul's elements (Nefesh, Ru'ach, Neshamah, Chayyah, Yehidah), methods of Torah interpretation (Pardes: Peshat, Remez, Derash, Sōd), historical development, and primary texts like the Zohar and Sefer Yetzirah.

Explores the diversity of Vodou practices across Haiti and its diaspora, noting variations in initiation rites and the absence of a central authority. It describes ceremonies involving Catholic prayers, African songs, and spirit possession, addressing common myths and misconceptions (e.g., voodoo dolls, Satanism) by contextualizing its folk magic elements.

Presents Wicca as a Neopagan religion and modern witchcraft, founded by Gerald Gardner. It describes Wicca as typically duotheistic, worshiping a Goddess (Triple Goddess, Moon Goddess) and a God (Horned God, Green Man), with various theological interpretations. It covers practices like ritual magic, Sabbats, Esbats, rites of passage (initiation, handfasting), and the significance of the Book of Shadows.

Defines wizardry as magically affecting the world through spells, rituals, or desires, viewed as a biological or acquired skill. It traces the historical perception of wizards (from mentors to villains) and the legal punishments for sorcery in ancient codes like Hammurabi and the Hebrew Bible. It highlights wizards as keepers of secret knowledge connected to a divine source.

Explains necromancy as divination by evoking the dead, or 'nigromancy' ('black magic'). It posits belief in the soul's survival and its superior knowledge. It covers the historical prevalence of necromancy in antiquity (Chaldea, Babylon, Greece, Rome, Jewish Bible), and describes modern practitioners as 'death magic' users who manipulate 'Malach Ha Mavet' (Angel of Death).

structure_content.chapter_title: Get ready to Think / Reading materials
structure_content.summary: Challenges the reader to adopt an open mind, question beliefs, and change perspectives to delve into sorcery. It introduces 'The Grimoire' as the written legacy of magicians, containing symbols, protocols, and invocations, representing a bridge from the mundane to the supernatural. It also emphasizes further reading from ancient scrolls and texts.

Describes Kabbalah as Jewish mysticism involving speculation on divinity, creation, and the soul. It differentiates Jewish mystical Kabbalah from Western or Hermetic Kabala. The 'Sepher ha Zohar' is highlighted as a foundational and influential text, covering esoteric commentary on the Pentateuch and theosophical concepts within God.

Presents 'The Book of the Dead' as an ancient Egyptian funerary text, a collection of spells, charms, and magical formulas for guiding the deceased through the afterlife. It emphasizes that knowledge of these spells was essential for achieving happiness beyond death, indicating its operative nature for the deceased.

Identifies the 'Sefer Yetzirah' ('Book of Creation') as the earliest extant Jewish esoteric text, attributed to Abraham. It details its focus on God's creation of the world and its significant influence on Jewish thought, including rabbinic accounts of rabbis creating a calf using its teachings. It notes the text's obscure style and multiple versions.

Briefly describes 'Sefer Raziel HaMalakh' as a magical text containing spells and amulets. It is presented as a practical resource for magical workings, aligning with the book's focus on operative magic.

Introduces 'Sefer Ha-Bahir' ('Book of the Brightness') as an anonymous mystical work of Jewish esotericism, attributed to Rabbi Nehunya Ben ha-Kanah and first published in the 12th century. It is identified as an early foundational text that contributed to what later became known as Kabbalah.

Positions the 'Emerald Tablet' as a cornerstone of the Hermetic movement and Alchemy, attributed to Hermes Trismegistus. It notes its ancient, unknown origin and its influence on alchemical development, including its study by Isaac Newton and its connection by C.G. Jung to Jungian individuation processes.

structure_content.chapter_title: The Lesser Keys of Solomon (Book for Necromancers)
structure_content.summary: Describes this as an anonymous 17th-century Grimoire and popular demonology book, detailing descriptions of spirits and conjurations. It outlines protective signs, rituals, and instructions for making instruments, emphasizing its utility for summoning and obliging spirits for the conjurer's will. It also refers to 'The Goetia' as a key translation.

Introduces the demons from the 'Ars Goetia,' noting variations in names and rankings from Weyer's 'Pseudomonarchia Daemonum.' It recommends starting with Goetia for beginners due to its simpler spells and rituals, promising quick effects.

Explores the fundamental connection between language and magic, where alphabets and words are seen as symbols accessing or guiding magical power. It presents various magical alphabets (Enochian, Futhark, Gothic, Adamic, Sumerian, Archaic Egyptian, Ancient Greek) and emphasizes the importance of understanding their specific sounds and meanings for effective spellcasting and ritual.

Encourages self-reflection on one's magical path (protective, combative, enchantments) and confronting the 'most difficult question of magic.' It introduces 'Mana' as personal magical power, cultivated through experience and constant regeneration, and distinguishes conjurers/necromancers (calling higher powers) from dark/white wizards/mages (cultivating Mana through meditation).

Critiques the common understanding of enlightenment as a singular state, proposing it as a multifaceted process. It highlights various paths to enlightenment (intellectual, psychological, devotional, energetic, shamanic, mystical) and emphasizes the importance of self-discovery over strict adherence to rigid doctrines from 'spiritual fundamentalists' like Jed McKenna.

Examines magical thinking as nonscientific causal reasoning, often involving correlation mistaken for causation, and the power of symbols, metaphors, and synchronicity. It discusses theories from Frazer (contagious/sympathetic magic), Levy-Bruhl ('collective representations'), Malinowski (sacred language), and Freud (cognitive developmental factors), linking it to the ability to affect one's environment through thought, inspired by 'The Matrix'.

Advocates meditation as the primary means to achieve enlightenment, emphasizing the control of one's attention. It notes that each magician has a unique method, but the core principle involves maintaining absolute stillness of attention. This state is presented as key to gaining perfect realization and making subsequent magical actions meaningful.

Explains meditation as a practice to achieve a calm, peaceful mind, free from worries and negativity, essential for effective magic. It details how meditation purifies the mind from negative karma, accumulates merit, and enables the practitioner to receive blessings, leading to 'purer and mightier forms of magic.'

Outlines breathing meditation as a preliminary practice to calm the mind and reduce distractions before magical meditation. It provides a 'Simple Breathing Meditation' technique focused on visualizing breathing away negative thoughts (black smoke) and breathing in blessings (white light), aiming for mental equilibrium and confidence in magical abilities.

Details five essential stages for successful magical meditation: Preparation (purifying negativity, accumulating merit, receiving blessings), Contemplation (bringing object to mind), Meditation (single-minded concentration), Dedication (directing merit), and Subsequent Practice (integrating meditation into daily life). It emphasizes careful preparation and consistent practice for 'Magical realizations.'

Discusses the power of Mantras, chants, and prayer wheels in magic. It explains that mantras harness energy from the 'Quantum Ocean' or 'Mind of God,' manifesting thoughts into physical reality. It provides examples of powerful mantras for white and black magicians, emphasizing repetition and quiet intonation.

Provides a step-by-step guide to practicing witchcraft, covering choosing a tradition, extensive research (books, online), finding a mentor, respecting nature, learning herbs, believing in witchcraft's energy, consistent practice, and studying pagan mythologies. It advises caution when joining groups and clarifies misconceptions like devil worship.

Offers steps for practicing Celtic Druidism, focusing on connecting with nature through daily meditation (30 min-2 hours), entering trances, creating a personal belief system, crafting a spell book with natural spells/healing/herbs/purification, and visiting sacred sites like Stonehenge to connect with ancient roots.

Provides practical steps for necromancy, including alternating between calling spirits and projecting energy, meditating in graveyards to connect with the dead, learning self-hypnosis for trance states, and understanding one's 'End Goal.' It issues strong warnings about the dangers of necromancy, stressing the need for good intentions and respect for the dead to avoid psychological damage or 'Dybbuk.'

Presents two spells, a 'good spell' and an 'evil spell,' translated from Sumerian or Akkadian texts found in 'The Necronomicon' and the 'Pulsa De Nura.' It includes the 'Charm Against the Hordes of Demons' in both English and its original Hebrew text, emphasizing the importance of reading Hebrew for its performance and cautioning about bad karma with dark magic.

A step-by-step guide for creating a magical staff, an item for wizards, druids, magi, and necromancers. It outlines materials (knife, long stick, decorations, adhesive) and a five-step process: selecting a stick, scraping bark, carving to desired shape, charring, and customizing with various elements like leathers, crystals, runes, and metal wires, to connect with its energy.

A practical guide for crafting a magical wand, a tool for focusing energy in spells and rituals. It details a five-step process: finding an appealing stick (at least 13 inches), scraping bark, carving, charring for appearance/amplification, and customizing with leather, crystals, runes, or symbols. It advises blessing/consecrating the wand and warns against lending/borrowing.

structure_content.chapter_title: Creating a Magic Ring of Power (Very Advanced)
structure_content.summary: Presents an advanced magical practice for creating a 'Magic Ring of Power,' accessible only to practitioners at a progressive rank. It describes a ten-step process: designing the ring, creating a mold, gathering gold/silver, heating the metal in a crucible, pouring into the mold, reading a spell to transfer energy, removing/inspecting the cooled ring, and adding diamonds/jewelry or inscribing names for high-level magic.

Offers a method for creating a personal 'Palantir' (crystal ball) for communicating with spirits and divination. Steps include purchasing a real crystal ball, climbing a high mountain with it, meditating and transferring energy for three days, covering and protecting it from others, and placing it in a high magical location in one's home.

Explains Abramelin Oil as a ceremonial magical oil with recipes for both essential oil and macerated versions. It details the ingredients (myrrh, cinnamon, calamus/galangal, olive oil) and proportions, referencing its origins in 'The Book of Abramelin.' It also contrasts Samuel Mathers' and Aleister Crowley's versions, noting differences in scent, skin sensation, and digestive toxicity due to ingredient substitutions.

structure_content.chapter_title: Final Words / List of Books to Read
structure_content.summary: Concludes by encouraging continued practice, emphasizing reading, knowledge, and wisdom as the core of a wizard's power and purpose. It reiterates that magic is based on 'Mana' and provides a list of further reading, including 'Holy Books of Thelema' and 'The Book of the Law,' for those committed to the academic and practical path of Wizardry.

key_concepts.definition: A state of profound self-realization and inner peace, cultivated through meditation, enabling a practitioner to connect with higher powers and effectively manifest magical intent. It is presented as a multifaceted process rather than a singular event.

The immaterial, eternal part of God within all beings and objects. Kabbalah describes five elements (Nephesh, Ru'ah, Neshamah, Chayyah, Yehidah) representing different levels of spiritual awareness. Egyptian traditions include Ba (personality), Ka (life force), and Akh (effective spirit of the dead).

A textbook of magic, serving as a written legacy for magicians. It contains symbols, protocols, invocations, spells, and instructions for invoking spirits, performing divination, and gaining magical powers, bridging the mundane and supernatural.

The personal magical power or life-energy of a practitioner, which can be cultivated and regenerated through consistent practice, especially meditation. It is the foundation for casting spells and operating magical tools.

The practice of communicating with the spirits of the dead, or raising the dead, for divination, prophecy, or other purposes. It is considered a form of death magic, often involving specific rituals and an understanding of the relationship with the Angel of Death.

The use of specific words, alphabets, chants, or phrases that are believed to have inherent power to influence the universe and guide magical energies. It is distinct from scientific language, being emotive and symbolic, and is crucial for effective spellcasting.

A ceremonial magical anointing oil, blended from aromatic plant materials (myrrh, cinnamon, calamus/galangal, olive oil). It is used in various modern occult traditions for consecration and to enhance magical operations.

A specific meditation posture, similar to Buddhist traditions, designed to aid concentration, develop a clear mind, and facilitate the free flow of subtle energy winds by maintaining a straight but relaxed back, specific hand positions, and focused gaze.

key_concepts.term: The Quantum Ocean / Mind of God
key_concepts.definition: A concept described as an infinite ocean of thinking, intelligent energy that responds to thoughts and words. It is presented as the source from which mantras derive their powerful vibrations and where manifested reality originates.

A specific grimoire detailed in 'The Lesser Keys of Solomon' that describes 72 demons and provides detailed instructions for their summoning and command, along with protective rituals and the necessary instruments for magical operations.

practical_system.description: The practical system outlined in the book is a holistic, multi-layered approach to magic, emphasizing both internal cultivation and external ritual practice. It begins with 'Magical Enlightenment' through rigorous meditation, which is seen as the foundation for developing 'Mana' (personal magical power) and gaining spiritual clarity. This internal work is then applied to various external practices, including spellcasting, demon summoning, spirit communication, and the creation and consecration of magical tools. The system integrates elements from diverse traditions like Ceremonial Magic, Wicca, Druidism, and Necromancy, with a strong emphasis on the practitioner's intent, ethical responsibility, and constant study.
tools: Grimoires (e.g., Book of Conjurations, Book of Shadows, Lesser Keys of Solomon, Sefer Raziel HaMalakh)
Staff (for wizards, druids, magi, necromancers, created from wood)
Wand (for focusing energy in spells, created from wood)
Magic Ring of Power (advanced, created from gold/silver)
Crystal Ball (for communication with spirits and divination)
Magical Alphabets (Enochian, Futhark, Gothic, Adamic, Sumerian, Archaic Egyptian, Ancient Greek)
Ritual implements (altar, dagger, chain, crown, robe, lamen, pentacle, chalice, broomstick, cauldron, candles, incense, curved blade)
rituals: Magical Meditation (including Breathing Meditations and 'Wizard's Posture')
Prayers for Meditation (Refuge, Bodhichitta, Necromancer, White Wizard, Druid specific prayers)
Mantra Recitation (for healing, protection, attraction, manifestation)
Spell Casting (using words, formulas, ritual actions)
Demon Summoning (using grimoires like Goetia, for command or petition)
Spirit Communication (with the dead for divination/prophecy)
Wiccan Sabbats and Esbats (seasonal and moon-based festivals)

relevant_quotes.text: Full Guide To Becoming a Real Wizard, Witch or Necromancer

The content of this book is based upon the scripts of Osari the Wise. You may have never heard his name before, which is the essence of becoming a real wizard - you seek the approval of God, no one else.
"A sorcerer shall not be allowed to live. " (Exodus 22: !7)
You must be starving for knowledge and wisdom, for you will spend hours reading and practicing every day.

The soul is, in reality. God's image in you; you are. in fact. an avatar - monitored by your soul from within your body, or outside of it. The Jewish Book of Genesis introduced the magical views of the soul. Verse 2:7 states: "Hashem (God) formed man from the dust of the earth. He blew into his nostrils the breath of life, and man became a living being"

Osari the Wise claim that magic. by contrast. is effective by virtue of the operation itself and by the strength of the magician·s will; Alternatively. the magician believes he can command the spiritual beings addressed by his spells.

"From the moment of creation, you are a daydreamer: you Imagine. think and never stop fantasizing, just as a child should .. As you grow. your guardians force you to acknowledge lheir reality: slowly kiling the wizard Inside you. This trickery was invented by mystery destroyers and magic murderers, and the only way to defeat It, is if we will all return to our childhood state. day dreaming and fantasizing. w - (Osarl the Wlse:1907.)

"SOme books cannot be opened with impunity. Enlightenment such-as-this is a loss of innocence, for you cannot unlearn Magick nor-then live in a fool's paradise; blind to good & evil or deaf from truth... this adventure is one-way... crossing the threshold of ignorance and shedding the veil of convention... prepare to se great things... prepare to experience your magnificent self..." -Oliver 1. Spence
"For everyone who asks receives; he who seeks finds; And to him who knocks, the door will be opened" - Joshua son of Joseph (Jesus Christ)
Believe me - you do not want to see the deao unless you are aware or your choice to see tnem.

critical_analysis.relevance: This book provides a highly relevant, albeit unconventional, framework for understanding and engaging with various esoteric traditions. It attempts to bridge historical magical practices with contemporary spiritual development, emphasizing a personal connection to the divine as the source of magical power. Its unique contribution lies in its attempt to synthesize different occult paths into a cohesive, albeit sometimes generalized, 'Full Guide,' making it a resource for those seeking to explore magic beyond specific dogmas.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The target audience is individuals seriously interested in becoming active practitioners of magic, including aspiring wizards, witches, necromancers, and druids. It appeals to those seeking a structured, step-by-step approach to spiritual and magical development, individuals open to challenging conventional religious and rationalistic views, and those with a strong desire for knowledge, self-mastery, and a deeper connection to the 'divine' or 'cosmic energy' through occult practices.
